title.value: RAMEN identifies effective indicators for severe COVID and Long COVID patients
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: RAMEN identifies effective indicators for severe COVID and Long COVID patients

extractions.description: The paper presents RAMEN, a method using Genetic Algorithm and random walks to infer Bayesian relationship networks between clinical variables associated with COVID-19. It demonstrates the use of RAMEN on a comprehensive COVID-19 dataset to identify effective indicators for severe COVID and long COVID outcomes.

type.justification: The study involves the use of a novel method (RAMEN) on actual datasets to empirically verify its effectiveness in identifying indicators for COVID-19 outcomes.
type.quote: We applied RAMEN to a comprehensive COVID-19 dataset, Biobanque Québécoise de la COVID-19 (BQC19).

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on predicting the relationships between clinical variables and COVID-19 outcomes.
name.quote: The accurate inference of the relationships between clinical variables and disease outcomes powered by RAMEN will significantly advance the development of effective and early diagnostics of severe COVID-19 and long COVID.

name.justification: The paper heavily discusses the construction and use of Bayesian networks as part of the RAMEN method.
name.quote: Graphical models (e.g., Bayesian networks) can address these limitations but are computationally expensive, which substantially limits their applications in reconstructing relationship networks of umpteen clinical variables.

name.justification: The method involves Genetic Algorithm and random walks, which are techniques within the machine learning domain.
name.quote: We propose RAMEN (Random walk and genetic Algorithm based network inference) that glues random walk and Genetic Algorithm to infer a Bayesian network.

name.justification: The main model proposed and used in the paper is RAMEN
name.quote: In this study, we have developed a method named RAMEN, which employs Genetic Algorithm and random walks to infer the Bayesian relationship network between clinical variables.

is_contributed.justification: RAMEN is introduced and developed by the authors within this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this study, we have developed a method named RAMEN.

is_executed.justification: RAMEN was applied to the BQC19 dataset within the study.
is_executed.quote: We applied RAMEN to a comprehensive COVID-19 dataset, Biobanque Québécoise de la COVID-19 (BQC19).

is_compared.justification: RAMEN's performance was computationally verified against literature and with statistical examinations.
is_compared.quote: Most of the clinical variables in our reconstructed Bayesian network associated with COVID-19 severity, or long COVID, are supported by existing literature.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no referenced paper title for RAMEN as it is unique to this study.

name.justification: The BQC19 is the primary dataset used in this study.
name.quote: We applied RAMEN to a comprehensive COVID-19 dataset, Biobanque Québécoise de la COVID-19 (BQC19).

referenced_paper_title.value: The Biobanque québécoise de la COVID-19 (BQC19)—A cohort to prospectively study the clinical and biological determinants of COVID-19 clinical trajectories
referenced_paper_title.justification: This reference discusses the dataset used in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Tremblay, K. et al. The Biobanque québécoise de la COVID-19 (BQC19)—A cohort to prospectively study the clinical and biological determinants of COVID-19 clinical trajectories. PloS one 16, e0245031 (2021).

name.justification: Cytoscape was used for network visualization.
name.quote: The reconstructed networks were visualized using Cytoscape.

referenced_paper_title.value: Cytoscape: a software environment for integrated models of biomolecular interaction networks
referenced_paper_title.justification: This reference discusses the Cytoscape library used in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Shannon, P. et al. Cytoscape: a software environment for integrated models of biomolecular interaction networks. Genome research 13, 2498-2504 (2003).
